That progressive branding hurts the party. Gallup:  >**Support for a more moderate Democratic Party among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents has grown by 11 percentage points, to 45%, since 2021.** At the same time, Democrats’ and leaners’ desire for a more liberal party has declined five points, to 29%, and preferences for no change in party ideology have fallen nine points, to 22%.  >[https://news.gallup.com/poll/656636/democrats-favor-party-moderation-past.aspx](https://news.gallup.com/poll/656636/democrats-favor-party-moderation-past.aspx)  That should not be a surprise, as typical Democratic voters are largely *not* progressive / very liberal.  >The Democratic coalition is more ideologically mixed than the Republican coalition. Progressives are a subset of the 42% of Biden voters who were liberal in that survey.  There is a reason why the GOP tries to brand the Democrats as a progressive / leftist party: Because that brand helps Republicans.  There are pathways to bringing universal healthcare to the US. Comment: The blunt reality is that reliable political support has to come from core issues that people are dealing with every day, all the time. One way to do that is through mass messaging and a media network under your political influence, but there's no "leftist media" of any significance to drive that. The other way to do that is to pick universal issues that directly hit most people - grocery prices, costs at the doctor/hospital, debt, home ownership, etc.  Deportations without due process are a huge issue, yes, particularly where it even hits citizens. But there's enough people with a gut reaction of "well I don't look like them so I won't ever be in those shoes" that they can forget about it the next day, and that's the problem.  One thing people on the left do need to remember that politics is an enthusiasm contest, not a morality one. Democracy is a cruel mistress - it's just better than all the alternatives.
